title: Should you trust unanimous decisions? - Derek Abbott

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon is described in the transcript where the reliability of a result decreases as it approaches total agreement?

options.label: A
options.text: The paradox of disagreement

options.label: B
options.text: The paradox of unanimity

options.label: C
options.text: The law of averages

options.label: D
options.text: The principle of relativity

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a situation where unanimous agreement is expected and reliable?

options.label: A
options.text: Identifying the bank robber in a police lineup

options.label: B
options.text: Identifying the apple in a lineup

options.label: C
options.text: Tossing a coin one hundred times

options.label: D
options.text: Voting in a presidential election

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected outcome when tossing a coin one hundred times?

options.label: A
options.text: Getting heads every time

options.label: B
options.text: Getting tails every time

options.label: C
options.text: Getting heads somewhere around 50% of the time

options.label: D
options.text: Getting an equal number of heads and tails

multiple-choice.question: According to a 1994 study, what percentage of witnesses tend to pick the wrong person out of a lineup, even when many are confident in their choice?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 20%

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 30%

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 40%

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 48%

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a situation where a unanimous identification should be viewed as a systemic error or bias in the lineup?

options.label: A
options.text: A witness confidently identifying the bank robber in a police lineup

options.label: B
options.text: A witness confidently identifying the apple in a lineup

options.label: C
options.text: A witness consistently picking the wrong person out of a lineup

options.label: D
options.text: A witness being unsure about their identification

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for the consistent DNA evidence found in multiple crime scenes around Europe from 1993-2008?

options.label: A
options.text: The DNA evidence was accurate

options.label: B
options.text: The DNA evidence was contaminated

options.label: C
options.text: The DNA evidence was deliberately planted

options.label: D
options.text: The DNA evidence was destroyed

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the presidential referendum held by Saddam Hussein in 2002?

options.label: A
options.text: A turnout of 50% of voters with 50% voting in favor

options.label: B
options.text: A turnout of 100% of voters with 100% voting in favor

options.label: C
options.text: A turnout of 75% of voters with 75% voting in favor

options.label: D
options.text: A turnout of 25% of voters with 25% voting in favor

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to understanding the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: Considering the overall level of uncertainty involved in the situation

options.label: B
options.text: Considering the number of people involved in the situation

options.label: C
options.text: Considering the type of situation being dealt with

options.label: D
options.text: Considering the time of day

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, why should a perfect result seem too good to be true?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is always possible to achieve perfection

options.label: B
options.text: Because error and disagreement are naturally expected in many situations

options.label: C
options.text: Because the result is always accurate

options.label: D
options.text: Because the result is always reliable

multiple-choice.question: What is the takeaway message from the transcript about the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: Unanimous agreement is always reliable

options.label: B
options.text: Unanimous agreement is never reliable

options.label: C
options.text: Unanimous agreement is reliable in some situations but not others

options.label: D
options.text: Unanimous agreement is not always possible

title: En el interior de tu computadora u ordenador | Bettina Bair |

multiple-choice.question: What are some key features of sustainable buildings?

options.label: A
options.text: They prioritize aesthetics and energy efficiency over environmental aspects and cost-effectiveness

options.label: B
options.text: They use renewable energy sources, incorporate natural light and ventilation, and have a high level of insulation

options.label: C
options.text: They focus only on cost-effectiveness and budget constraints

options.label: D
options.text: They have high energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions

multiple-choice.question: What are some benefits of sustainable buildings?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced air quality, increased energy consumption, and decreased indoor comfort

options.label: B
options.text: Improved air quality, reduced energy consumption, and increased water efficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Higher operating costs and decreased indoor comfort

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased indoor air quality and increased energy consumption

multiple-choice.question: What factors do sustainable building designs consider?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the availability of construction materials and budget constraints

options.label: B
options.text: The building's orientation, insulation, materials used in construction, and natural light and ventilation

options.label: C
options.text: Only the interior design and layout

options.label: D
options.text: Only the exterior design and appearance

multiple-choice.question: What are some examples of sustainable building features?

options.label: A
options.text: Artificial lighting and heating systems, high energy-consuming appliances, and lack of insulation

options.label: B
options.text: Solar panels, wind turbines, natural light and ventilation systems, and energy-efficient appliances

options.label: C
options.text: Insulation and energy-efficient systems, but not energy-efficient appliances

options.label: D
options.text: High energy-consuming appliances and artificial lighting

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of sustainable building practices?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions

options.label: C
options.text: To be cost-effective and meet minimum building codes

options.label: D
options.text: To only be socially responsible and focus on aesthetics

multiple-choice.question: How do sustainable buildings contribute to the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions

options.label: B
options.text: By reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions

options.label: C
options.text: By only being cost-effective and meeting minimum building codes

options.label: D
options.text: By only being socially responsible and focusing on aesthetics

title: Why the insect brain is so incredible - Anna St√∂ckl

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where different species evolve similar traits in response to similar environmental pressures?

options.label: A
options.text: Divergent evolution

options.label: B
options.text: Convergent evolution

options.label: C
options.text: Parallel evolution

options.label: D
options.text: Adaptive radiation

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the human nervous system and the insect nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of neurons in the brain

options.label: B
options.text: The way the nervous system is organized, with the human system working like a monarchy and the insect system working like a decentralized federation

options.label: C
options.text: The way the brain controls the body

options.label: D
options.text: The way the body senses the environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process by which an insect can still walk, scratch itself, breathe, and even fly after losing its head?

options.label: A
options.text: Decentralized control

options.label: B
options.text: Centralized control

options.label: C
options.text: Hierarchical control

options.label: D
options.text: Distributed control

multiple-choice.question: What are the main functions of an insect's brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To control the body's movements and regulate communication and navigation

options.label: B
options.text: To perceive the world through sight and smell and regulate communication and navigation

options.label: C
options.text: To perceive the world through sight and smell, regulate communication and navigation, and choose suitable mates

options.label: D
options.text: To all of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the study of how neurons work together in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Neuroscience

options.label: B
options.text: Neurology

options.label: C
options.text: Neurophysiology

options.label: D
options.text: Neural dynamics

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of neurons in the human brain?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 million

options.label: B
options.text: 100 million

options.label: C
options.text: 86 billion

options.label: D
options.text: 1 trillion

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process by which scientists study the comparison between insect and human brains to understand which brain functions are unique and which are general solutions to evolutionary problems?

options.label: A
options.text: Comparative neuroscience

options.label: B
options.text: Evolutionary neuroscience

options.label: C
options.text: Convergent evolution

options.label: D
options.text: Brain-computer interface

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of neurons in an insect's brain?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 million

options.label: B
options.text: 10 million

options.label: C
options.text: 100 million

options.label: D
options.text: Less than 1 million

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where birds, bats, and bees separately evolved wings?

options.label: A
options.text: Convergent evolution

options.label: B
options.text: Divergent evolution

options.label: C
options.text: Parallel evolution

options.label: D
options.text: Adaptive radiation

multiple-choice.question: Why are scientists fascinated by insect brains?

options.label: A
options.text: Their complexity and size

options.label: B
options.text: Their simplicity and small size, which makes it easier to understand how neurons work together in the brain

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to fly

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to walk

title: What is Minimalist Art And Why Does it Matter?

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary focus of minimalism in the context of the 1960s art movement?

options.label: A
options.text: A general sensibility or lifestyle trend

options.label: B
options.text: A rejection of abstract expressionism and a focus on geometric, abstract art

options.label: C
options.text: A movement that emphasizes the importance of the artist's personal experiences and emotions

options.label: D
options.text: A style that prioritizes the use of bright colors and bold patterns

multiple-choice.question: Which art critic attacked minimalism in 1967 for being theatrical?

options.label: A
options.text: Michael Fried

options.label: B
options.text: Robert Morris

options.label: C
options.text: Donald Judd

options.label: D
options.text: Ellsworth Kelly

multiple-choice.question: What term was used by art critics to describe the work of minimalists in the 1960s?

options.label: A
options.text: Minimalism

options.label: B
options.text: ABC art, object art, primary structures, and cool art

options.label: C
options.text: Abstract expressionism

options.label: D
options.text: Geometric art

multiple-choice.question: According to Robert Morris, what was the artist's response to the work of minimalists?

options.label: A
options.text: A resounding yes to transcendence and spiritual values

options.label: B
options.text: A resounding no to transcendence and spiritual values

options.label: C
options.text: A mixture of both yes and no

options.label: D
options.text: A complete rejection of the work

multiple-choice.question: What was the goal of minimalism in terms of the relationship between the viewer and the art?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a sense of intimacy and connection between the viewer and the art

options.label: B
options.text: To abandon the pedestal and dismantle the separation between the viewer and the art

options.label: C
options.text: To create a sense of distance and detachment between the viewer and the art

options.label: D
options.text: To emphasize the importance of the artist's personal experiences and emotions

multiple-choice.question: Which artist described his work as a kind of plastic poetry?

options.label: A
options.text: Donald Judd

options.label: B
options.text: Carl Andre

options.label: C
options.text: Dan Flavin

options.label: D
options.text: Sol LeWitt

multiple-choice.question: What was the meaning of minimalism in the context of the 1960s art movement?

options.label: A
options.text: The meaning was inherent in the object itself

options.label: B
options.text: The meaning was in the context, and existed in the viewer's interaction with it

options.label: C
options.text: The meaning was a combination of both the object and the context

options.label: D
options.text: The meaning was irrelevant to the art movement

multiple-choice.question: How did the fetishization and commodification of minimalist art complicate and pollute the ideas of minimalism?

options.label: A
options.text: It made the art more accessible and appealing to a wider audience

options.label: B
options.text: It created a sense of detachment and distance between the viewer and the art

options.label: C
options.text: It made the art more expensive and exclusive

options.label: D
options.text: It complicated and polluted the ideas of minimalism by making it less real and more about the value of the object

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of minimalism on the viewer's experience in the gallery?

options.label: A
options.text: It created a sense of confusion and disorientation

options.label: B
options.text: It made the viewer feel more connected to the art and the gallery

options.label: C
options.text: It made the viewer aware of their own body in the gallery and the relationship between the viewer and the art

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the viewer's experience

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of minimalism in the context of the 1960s art movement?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a minor movement that had little impact on the art world

options.label: B
options.text: It was a major movement that changed the way people thought about art and the relationship between the viewer and the art

options.label: C
options.text: It was a movement that emphasized the importance of the artist's personal experiences and emotions

options.label: D
options.text: It was a style that prioritized the use of bright colors and bold patterns

multiple-choice.question: According to the artist Sol LeWitt, what was the best way to approach the basic unit of minimal art?

options.label: A
options.text: To make it deliberately interesting

options.label: B
options.text: To make it deliberately uninteresting

options.label: C
options.text: To make it a combination of both interesting and uninteresting

options.label: D
options.text: To make it a complete rejection of the concept of minimal art

multiple-choice.question: What was the goal of minimalism in terms of the viewer's interaction with the art?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a sense of intimacy and connection between the viewer and the art

options.label: B
options.text: To encourage observation and interaction, but not to draw the viewer in

options.label: C
options.text: To create a sense of distance and detachment between the viewer and the art

options.label: D
options.text: To emphasize the importance of the artist's personal experiences and emotions

multiple-choice.question: Which artist claimed that the works of minimalists were neither painting nor sculpture, but specific objects occupying real space?

options.label: A
options.text: Donald Judd

options.label: B
options.text: Carl Andre

options.label: C
options.text: Dan Flavin

options.label: D
options.text: Sol LeWitt

multiple-choice.question: What was the meaning of minimalism in the context of the 1960s art movement, according to the artist Carl Andre?

options.label: A
options.text: The meaning was inherent in the object itself

options.label: B
options.text: The meaning was in the context, and existed in the viewer's interaction with it

options.label: C
options.text: The meaning was a combination of both the object and the context

options.label: D
options.text: The meaning was irrelevant to the art movement

multiple-choice.question: What was the term used by art critics to describe the rejection of abstract expressionism and a focus on geometric, abstract art?

options.label: A
options.text: Minimalism

options.label: B
options.text: ABC art, object art, primary structures, and cool art

options.label: C
options.text: Abstract expressionism

options.label: D
options.text: Geometric art

title: Proof of Evolution That You Can Find on Your Body

options.text: Evolutionary remnants

options.label: C
options.text: Atavisms

options.label: D
options.text: Body anomalies

options.label: B
options.text: Bicep

options.label: C
options.text: Tricep

options.label: D
options.text: Flexor

options.text: Auditory response

title: How do schools of fish swim in harmony? - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What term is used to describe the spontaneous creation of sophisticated behaviors and functions from large groups of simple elements?

options.label: A
options.text: Emergence

options.label: B
options.text: Reductionism

options.label: C
options.text: Complexity Theory

options.label: D
options.text: Chaos Theory

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are the two basic rules that individual fish in a school follow?

options.label: A
options.text: Follow the school leader and stay close to each other

options.label: B
options.text: Stay close, but not too close, to your neighbor, and keep swimming

options.label: C
options.text: Swim in a straight line and avoid predators

options.label: D
options.text: Dive deep and stay there

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists understand complex systems like a school of fish?

options.label: A
options.text: By taking them apart and studying their individual components

options.label: B
options.text: By observing the emergent patterns that arise from the interactions of individual components

options.label: C
options.text: By reducing them to simple mathematical equations

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring their complex behavior and focusing on their individual parts

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if you reduced a school of fish to individual fish?

options.label: A
options.text: The school would become more efficient at evading predators

options.label: B
options.text: The school would lose the ability to evade predators

options.label: C
options.text: The school would become more disorganized

options.label: D
options.text: The school would become more organized

multiple-choice.question: What is the basic function of each neuron in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To generate complex patterns of activity

options.label: B
options.text: To either excite or inhibit other neurons

options.label: C
options.text: To store memories

options.label: D
options.text: To transmit signals

multiple-choice.question: How do the neurons in the brain follow simple rules to self-organize into reliable patterns?

options.label: A
options.text: By interacting with each other and following simple rules, such as excitation and inhibition

options.label: B
options.text: By generating complex patterns of activity

options.label: C
options.text: By following a single leader neuron

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring each other and acting independently

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between chaos and emergence in complex systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Chaos can lead to emergence

options.label: B
options.text: Emergence can lead to chaos

options.label: C
options.text: Chaos and emergence are unrelated

options.label: D
options.text: Chaos and emergence are mutually exclusive

multiple-choice.question: What is the characteristic of emergence that is common across different scales and systems?

options.label: A
options.text: The need for a single leader

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to reduce complex systems to simple components

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to self-organize into reliable patterns without a leader

options.label: D
options.text: The need for external control

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists study emergent phenomena in complex systems?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing the emergent patterns that arise from the interactions of individual components

options.label: B
options.text: By reducing them to simple mathematical equations

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring their complex behavior and focusing on their individual parts

options.label: D
options.text: By using computer simulations

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of emergence in understanding complex systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Emergence is a fundamental property of complex systems that allows them to self-organize and adapt

options.label: B
options.text: Emergence is a rare and unusual phenomenon that is not relevant to most complex systems

options.label: C
options.text: Emergence is a byproduct of complex systems that is not relevant to their behavior

options.label: D
options.text: Emergence is a property of simple systems that is not relevant to complex systems

title: Can you solve the locker riddle? - Lisa Winer

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: How many relatives are invited to the reading of the will?
**Comprehension**: What is the condition for the heir to get the entire inheritance all to themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: If they are the first to solve the problem

options.label: B
options.text: If they answer the puzzle correctly

options.label: C
options.text: If they find the pattern and solve the problem without going through all of the leg work

options.label: D
options.text: If they are the last one to solve the puzzle

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: A locker with the number 16 will be touched by how many people?
**Analysis**: What is the rule for determining whether a locker will remain open or closed?

options.label: A
options.text: If the locker number has an even number of factors, it will remain closed

options.label: B
options.text: If the locker number has an odd number of factors, it will remain closed

options.label: C
options.text: If the locker number has an even number of factors, it will remain open

options.label: D
options.text: If the locker number has an odd number of factors, it will remain open

multiple-choice.question: **Synthesis**: How can you determine which lockers will remain open at the end?

options.label: A
options.text: By counting the number of times each locker is touched

options.label: B
options.text: By finding the perfect squares among the locker numbers

options.label: C
options.text: By finding the prime numbers among the locker numbers

options.label: D
options.text: By counting the number of factors in each locker number

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: Is it a good idea to share the money evenly among all the relatives?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it is a fair and reasonable solution

options.label: B
options.text: No, it is not a good idea because it does not reward the person who solved the puzzle

options.label: C
options.text: Maybe, it depends on the circumstances

options.label: D
options.text: No, it is not a good idea because it does not take into account the effort required to solve the puzzle

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What is the pattern that the lawyer explains to the relatives?

options.label: A
options.text: Every relative is assigned a number from 1 to 100, and each heir will open every locker, then close every second locker, and so on

options.label: B
options.text: Every relative is assigned a number from 1 to 100, and each heir will change the status of every third locker

options.label: C
options.text: Every relative is assigned a number from 1 to 100, and each heir will open every locker, then close every second locker, and change the status of every third locker

options.label: D
options.text: Every relative is assigned a number from 1 to 100, and each heir will close every locker

multiple-choice.question: **Comprehension**: What is the code that the relative uses to open the safe?

options.label: A
options.text: The first five lockers touched only once

options.label: B
options.text: The first five lockers touched only twice

options.label: C
options.text: The last five lockers touched only once

options.label: D
options.text: The last five lockers touched only twice

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: Which lockers will remain open at the end?

options.label: A
options.text: The lockers with an even number of factors

options.label: B
options.text: The lockers with an odd number of factors

options.label: C
options.text: The lockers that are perfect squares

options.label: D
options.text: The lockers that are prime numbers

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: Is the solution to the puzzle fair and reasonable?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it is a fair and reasonable solution

options.label: B
options.text: No, it is not a fair and reasonable solution

options.label: C
options.text: Maybe, it depends on the circumstances

options.label: D
options.text: No, it is not a fair and reasonable solution because it does not take into account the effort required to solve the puzzle

title: The physics of the "hardest move" in ballet - Arleen Sugano

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the dancer's incredible ability to whip around without stopping in the fouett√© sequence?

options.label: A
options.text: Fouett√©s

options.label: B
options.text: Whipped

options.label: C
options.text: Torque

options.label: D
options.text: Angular momentum

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason the dancer pauses for a split second between each turn in the fouett√© sequence?

options.label: A
options.text: To generate new torque

options.label: B
options.text: To help her keep her balance

options.label: C
options.text: To store momentum in her elevated leg

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce friction

multiple-choice.question: A skilled dancer can keep her turning axis vertical by using her arms and torque-generating foot to drive the fouett√©. What is the benefit of this?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases her rotational inertia

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces her angular velocity

options.label: C
options.text: It helps her maintain her center of gravity

options.label: D
options.text: It generates more friction

multiple-choice.question: A really good ballerina can get more than one turn out of every leg extension in one of two ways. What are the two options?

options.label: A
options.text: She can extend her leg sooner or bring her arms closer to her body once she returns to pointe

options.label: B
options.text: She can extend her leg later or bring her arms farther away from her body once she returns to pointe

options.label: C
options.text: She can extend her leg sooner or later, but not bring her arms closer to her body

options.label: D
options.text: She can bring her arms closer to her body once she returns to pointe, but not extend her leg sooner

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between rotational inertia and the axis of rotation?

options.label: A
options.text: Rotational inertia increases when more mass is distributed closer to the axis of rotation

options.label: B
options.text: Rotational inertia decreases when more mass is distributed closer to the axis of rotation

options.label: C
options.text: Rotational inertia has no relationship with the axis of rotation

options.label: D
options.text: Rotational inertia is equal to the axis of rotation

multiple-choice.question: A really good ballerina can get more than one turn out of every leg extension in one of two ways. What is the underlying principle that makes this possible?

options.label: A
options.text: Conservation of angular momentum

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in rotational inertia

options.label: C
options.text: Decrease in angular velocity

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in friction

options.text: It requires a lot of strength and endurance

options.label: B
options.text: It involves a lot of complex movements and turns

options.label: C
options.text: It is governed by the principle of conservation of angular momentum

options.label: D
options.text: It is a slow and steady sequence

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the principle that states that the angular momentum of a system remains constant over time, unless acted upon by an external force?

options.label: A
options.text: Conservation of angular momentum

options.label: B
options.text: Conservation of energy

options.label: C
options.text: Conservation of momentum

options.label: D
options.text: Conservation of rotational inertia

multiple-choice.question: A really good ballerina can get more than one turn out of every leg extension in one of two ways. What is the benefit of extending her leg sooner?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases her rotational inertia

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces her angular velocity

options.label: C
options.text: It stores more momentum in her leg

options.label: D
options.text: It generates more friction

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the speed of a turn and the amount of mass distributed closer to the axis of rotation?

options.label: B
options.text: The speed of the turn decreases when more mass is distributed closer to the axis of rotation

options.label: C
options.text: The speed of the turn has no relationship with the amount of mass distributed closer to the axis of rotation

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: Ionizing and non-ionizing radiation

title: Can you solve the frog riddle? - Derek Abbott

multiple-choice.question: What is the antidote needed to save the person's life?

options.label: A
options.text: Excreted by a male species of frog

options.label: B
options.text: Excreted by a female species of frog

options.label: C
options.text: Found in a poisonous mushroom

options.label: D
options.text: Produced by the person's own body

multiple-choice.question: Why can't the person tell the male and female frogs apart?

options.label: A
options.text: They have different colors

options.label: B
options.text: They have different shapes

options.label: C
options.text: They look identical

options.label: D
options.text: They have different sizes

multiple-choice.question: A person is stranded in a huge rainforest and has eaten a poisonous mushroom. What should they do to increase their chances of survival?

options.label: A
options.text: Go to the tree stump and lick the frog there

options.label: B
options.text: Go to the clearing and lick both frogs there

options.label: C
options.text: Run away from the frogs

options.label: D
options.text: Stay where they are

multiple-choice.question: Why is the probability of getting a female frog in the clearing different from the probability of getting a female frog in the tree stump?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the number of male and female frogs is different

options.label: B
options.text: Because the frogs in the clearing are not independent of each other

options.label: C
options.text: Because the person has more information about the frogs in the clearing

options.label: D
options.text: Because the frogs in the clearing are not real

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that explains how additional information affects probability?

options.label: A
options.text: Conditional probability

options.label: B
options.text: Independent probability

options.label: C
options.text: Sample space

options.label: D
options.text: Probability distribution

multiple-choice.question: How does conditional probability work?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing the probability of getting a particular combination

options.label: B
options.text: By decreasing the probability of getting a particular combination

options.label: C
options.text: By leaving the probability of getting a particular combination unchanged

options.label: D
options.text: By eliminating possibilities and shrinking the sample space

multiple-choice.question: Why is it that the person has a 2/3 chance of survival if they go to the clearing and lick both frogs there?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the person has a 2/3 chance of getting a female frog in the clearing

options.label: B
options.text: Because the person has more information about the frogs in the clearing

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are two male frogs and only one female frog in the clearing

options.label: D
options.text: Because the person is less likely to get a male frog in the clearing

multiple-choice.question: What are some real-world applications of conditional probability?

options.label: A
options.text: Detecting likely errors in computer data

options.label: B
options.text: Making decisions based on past experience

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: How to increase the chances of survival in a rainforest

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of conditional probability

options.label: C
options.text: How to make decisions based on information

options.label: D
options.text: The relationship between information and probability

multiple-choice.question: What is the connection between conditional probability and the person's life decision?

options.label: A
options.text: Conditional probability is used to make decisions

options.label: B
options.text: Conditional probability is used to detect errors in data

options.label: C
options.text: Conditional probability is used to narrow down choices

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above
